image.altText: A young boy stands with his dad crouched next to him. There's a lake in the background.

items.synopsis: With nine years' experience and a strong desire to contribute to Australian society, Jonathon Wales is exactly the kind of person WA Police are looking for. But the Scottish's officer's son has autism, and that is a deal-breaker for the government.

title.children: We urgently need his dad's skills, but Australia says it can't afford to let this four-year-old in

image.altText: Indigenous woman wearing an orange top with her hand to her chest. A large bottle of water is behind her.

items.synopsis: First Nations health professionals and those living with chronic health issues say they are "disappointed" and "deeply saddened" following Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price's claims First Nations Australians are not living with ongoing negative impacts of colonisation.

title.children: 'I don't know where she gets information from': Aboriginal health workers 'saddened' by senator's colonisation claims

image.altText: Rough seas experienced on board RV Investigator in May 2018

items.synopsis: As one scientist put it, humans "know more about the moon than we do about the deep ocean", but this ship — and those on board —have just chalked up their 100th mission, attempting to redress the knowledge imbalance.

title.children: Scientists know on this ship it may get bumpy and 'anyone can get seasick'

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wearing a black hoodie with the "yes" logo on the front.

items.synopsis: There are another four weeks until Australians will officially cast their votes in the first referendum in more than two decades. For the Yes campaign, there is a path to success, albeit a narrow one, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: The comments that reveal just how clearly the No campaign is leading the Voice debate

image.altText: Russell Brand gestures as he talks.

items.synopsis: Brand, 48, says he received a letter and an email from a television company and a newspaper "listing a litany of extremely egregious and aggressive attacks".

title.children: Russell Brand denies 'serious criminal allegations' set to be aired in TV documentary

image.altText: Hugh Jackman, right., and Deborra-Lee Furness Jackman attend a movie premiere.

items.synopsis: The couple release a statement confirming their split after 27 years of marriage, saying they have decided to "pursue individual growth".

title.children: 'Our journey now is shifting': Hugh Jackman and Deborra-Lee Furness announce separation

image.altText: Craypots and a small boat at a water's edge, with a hill and lighthouse in background against a setting evening's sky.

items.synopsis: Life on King Island off the Tasmanian coast is full of trade-offs, especially when it comes to health care most Australians take for granted. But residents are trying to change that.

title.children: The hidden cost of living in an island paradise, and why it leaves some residents with PTSD

image.altText: Anthony Albanese (left) stands and shakes hands with Joe Biden in front of US and Australian flags.

items.synopsis: Two years since the AUKUS deal, some American politicians are calling for the US to step up its shipbuilding before selling subs to Australia, while others say Donald Trump's possible return to power means congress should move more quickly.

title.children: Prospect of another 'erratic' Trump presidency prompts call to move faster on AUKUS

image.altText: Donald Trump, in suit, speaks with reporters in front of a plane that has his name on it.

items.synopsis: A judge is being asked to impose limits on statements from former US president Donald Trump regarding a Washington DC court case over his attempt to overturn his 2020 election defeat.

title.children: Prosecutors seek narrow gag order on Donald Trump after 'inflammatory' public comments

image.altText: Queen Silvia dressed in a white gown and King Carl XVI Gustaf wearing a dark suit walk together in front of a guard.

items.synopsis: As some global royals come under the microscope for their role in modern society, it seems Sweden's king is more popular than ever, despite a scandal-plagued reign.

title.children: Sweden's King Carl, the playboy monarch who didn't want his daughter on the throne

image.altText: A map of the world with Australia at the fore and different coloured bands showing airmasses

items.synopsis: It's already feeling like summer. Temperatures in central and south-eastern Australia have climbed to 10 degrees Celsius above average and more hot weather is on the way.

title.children: Just two weeks out of winter and it's already feeling like summer. Here's why

image.altText: Two men hugging at a presentation night

items.synopsis: Seven former players, including Phil Krakouer, launch a class action against the AFL for failing to protect players from racial abuse

title.children: 'Sorry doesn't cut it': Phil Krakouer leads racism class action against AFL

image.altText: A person with long hair dyed pink and blue sits in a wheelchair with a beige jacket and black pants holding a microphone

items.synopsis: Discovering mobility aids have been damaged or broken during a flight is not new to anyone with a disability — but even disability advocate Akii Ngo was shocked by the state of their electric wheelchair after a Qantas flight last month. But it was the disorganised response that caused most distress

title.children: '100 per cent housebound': How a trip home on Qantas left Akii stranded

image.altText: Two women take a selfie in front of a statue of a woman with snakes for hair

items.synopsis: Many mythical female monsters were created to scare women and children into submission. Today they could have a very different meaning.

title.children: These female monsters once terrified people. Now, an expert says they should be admired

image.altText: Ashton Kutcher smiles wearing a suit in front of a screen with writing on it.

items.synopsis: American actor Ashton Kutcher resigns from the anti-child sex abuse charity he co-founded after writing a character reference for fellow That '70s Show actor Danny Masterson before he was sentenced for rape.

title.children: Ashton Kutcher resigns from charity after writing character letter for Danny Masterson

image.altText: A man with grey hair and moustache, wearing yellow firefighter overalls, stands with a young smiling woman.

items.synopsis: After 40 years fighting bushfires, and becoming increasingly alarmed at their intensity, Alan risked jail to join young climate activists like Violet. He's not alone and here's why

title.children: 'It's not their fault': Crackdown on climate activism sees older, law-abiding citizens risk jail to join the fight

image.altText: Close up of an angry spider lifting its front leg; scientist in the background.

items.synopsis: For arachnologist Jeremy Wilson, eight-legged wonders like this wishbone spider are well worth going bush for.

title.children: New species of burrowing spider unearthed in outback WA

image.altText: A comet flies through space, only blackness and a few stars are visible in the background.

items.synopsis: While Nishimura is definitely bright enough to be visible to the naked eye in dark skies, at best it will hug the horizon just after sunset — almost lost in the Sun's glow, writes Jonti Horner.

title.children: Are we about to see a rare green comet light up the sky?

image.altText: Toula from My Big Fat Greek Wedding sits at a table with her husband smiling at him, the ocean behind them

items.synopsis: When My Big Fat Greek Wedding came out more than 20 years ago, it made me feel seen as a member of the Greek diaspora. The third film isn't quite so impactful, but I still see myself in the story.

title.children: My Big Fat Greek Wedding 3 may be cheesy, but it captures the joy of second-generation migrants going 'home'

image.altText: man wearing white personal protective equipment sits while numerous makeshift gravestones can be seen behind him

items.synopsis: The WHO and other aid groups warn that mass grave burials to deal with flood deaths could cause risks of mental distress, cholera, and other health risks.

title.children: Devastating flood in Libya's Derna raises fear of cholera outbreak with corpses washing up or decaying under rubble

image.altText: A view showing buildings destoyed and surrounded by floodwater.

items.synopsis: Thousands have died after flooding Libya's coastal city of Derna. This is where you can donate to help people on the ground.

title.children: How to donate to help Libya as death toll from flooding grows

image.altText: A man in a yellow shirt and dirty face on a computer with other men on computers around him.

items.synopsis: China is working with neighbouring countries to crack down on the scam operations that are plaguing the region — including Australia.

title.children: Will China's scam crackdown have an effect in Australia?

image.altText: Row of black and red Teslas in a parking lot.

items.synopsis: A major car rental company was renting Teslas out for about one-third the cost of a petrol car. We figured, how different could it be?

title.children: I rented a Tesla for a month. It was a steep learning curve

image.altText: A Collingwood AFL player handballs during a match in the 2023 season.

items.synopsis: It hasn't been smooth sailing for Collingwood during its week off, with vice-captain Taylor Adams sidelined with a hamstring injury ahead of the Magpies' grand final qualifier.

title.children: Magpies hit with major injury blow ahead of AFL preliminary final

image.altText: A cast of actors dressed in 70s clothing sing and dance on a blue-lit stage. In the centre is Gough Whitlam holding up a beer.

items.synopsis: Australia's great constitutional crisis of 1975 has all the right ingredients for a musical: high stakes, flawed characters and Norman Gunston. Meet the Australian writers bringing politics to the stage.

title.children: 'Funnier than Hamilton': Australia's biggest political drama gets the musical comedy treatment

image.altText: Side shot of young woman in glasses with meditative expression looking out at a wetland.

items.synopsis: It started with "bits and pieces" of a language their elders were forbidden to hand down. Now Djinama Yilaga choir members are reclaiming the Dhurga language through song.

title.children: Once forbidden, this language is coming alive again — through song

image.altText: Human hands holding a pile of yellow fluffy seeds

items.synopsis: Seed banks say they need more government funding to plant native orchards to ever hope to reach regeneration targets.

title.children: Seed banks struggle to keep up with growing demand for biodiversity, revegetation projects

image.altText: A composite image of puppies laying on a towel

items.synopsis: A hiker and his dog found five, two-day-old puppies in bushland near Bendigo. On their way to good health, animal rescuers now want to reunite them with their mother.

title.children: Dumped puppies saved from 'certain death', now rescuers fear for their mother

image.altText: A small demon-like creature, the Knight, stands in a flowing blue cloak with a nail-like sword

items.synopsis: One of the most popular game development tools in the world announced new fees for using its service. It has left Australian game developers angry and perplexed — and could have ramifications for players, too.

title.children: 'Just devastating': Why your favourite video game creators are confused and furious right now

image.altText: A 1979 photo of a two-tier diving platform packed with people in board shorts and bikinis.

items.synopsis: One of the last remaining diving pools in Sydney is slated for closure, leaving only two publicly accessible diving facilities.

title.children: Diving platforms and springboards 'a thing of the past' as suburban pool-users trade fun for fitness

image.altText: At the centre is a thin horizontal pinkish cloud that is uneven with rounded ends, and tilted from bottom left to top right.

items.synopsis: The ultra-powerful telescope has allowed researchers to capture the speed of the outflows from a young star — beyond the ability of ground-based telescopes.

title.children: James Webb Space Telescope captures supersonic outflow of young star

image.altText: Man in suit points to chalkboard.

items.synopsis: When Robert Goddard thought he'd figured out how to get humans into space in 1920, the press called his ideas "absurd". Now, his ideas about rocket propulsion will help us create a petrol station on the Moon.

title.children: Robert Goddard's ideas were mocked a century ago. Now, his ideas will help build a petrol station on the Moon
